Authors: Derek S. Sikes, Logan John Mullen
Title:
Phylogeny and evolution of large body size in the rove beetle
genus Phlaeopterus Motschulsky, 1853 (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
Omaliinae: Anthophagini)
Keywords:
Phlaeopterus, Rove beetle, Staphylinidae, Vellica,
Lesteva, maximum likelihood, Bayesian, DNA barcoding
Abstract:
The omaliine rove beetle genus Phlaeopterus Motschulsky,
1853 contains 22 species. The genus is distributed across northwestern
North America and eastern Asia. These beetles occur primarily along the
edges of alpine snowfields and streams, habitats that are particularly
sensitive to the impacts of climate change. Two species have not been
collected since 1979 and 1984, one of which, Phlaeopterus bakerensis
Mullen and Campbell, 2018, is a contender for the largest-bodied species
among the over 1,500 species of the subfamily Omaliinae. Here, we
present the first phylogeny of the genus, using Bayesian and maximum
likelihood analyses based on DNA sequences from the mitochondrial gene
COI and morphological data. The COI, morphological, and combined
phylogenies agree in some respects but conflict in others. We tested
previous taxonomic hypotheses and most were rejected by all three
analyses. We regard two Phlaeopterus species found to be
non-monophyletic based on COI sequences to be distinct based on
morphology, and suggest that P. castaneus Casey, 1893 and P. loganensis
Hatch, 1957 may have hybridized. We found support for the monophyly of
the genus Phlaeopterus. Our analyses suggest the common ancestor of the
genus had small-bodied adults (maximum body size under 5 mm) with
ocelli. Within this small-bodied radiation of species ocelli were lost
once and there were two separate changes to large-bodied adults. These
findings represent the first modern phylogenetic reconstruction of
species-level relationships within the rove beetle subfamily Omaliinae
MacLeay, 1825 using both morphological and molecular data.
